content.question: A parallel-plate capacitor is connected in series with a battery and a <math alttext="30 ohm" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> resistor, as shown above. The capacitor consists of two circular metal plates with radius <math alttext="1.0 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that are separated only by a circular piece of paper with the same radius as the plates. When the capacitor is fully charged, each plate has an excess charge of magnitude <math alttext="9.0 times 10 to the negative 11 power, coulomb" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . The capacitor is replaced by a new capacitor made from two circular metal plates with radius <math alttext="2.0 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that are now separated by two circular pieces of paper with the same radius as the plates. What is the magnitude of the charge on each plate of the new capacitor after it is fully charged?
